newsitem.title: QATAR: Qatar eyeing six European states to market LNG.
newsitem.headline: Qatar eyeing six European states to market LNG.

text.p: Qatar is eyeing six European countries to market liquefied natural gas over the next decade, a local newspaper reported on Wednesday.
The countries named by the English-language Peninsula are Poland, Hungary, Austria, Bosnia, Spain and Croatia.

"Initial talks have been held with Poland, Austria, Croatia and Bosnia and we expect they will be able to take between 10 and 15 million tonnes a year of LNG from 2002 onward," said the paper, quoting an unnamed Qatar General Petroleum Corporation official.
"Bosnia has told us it would need 1.5 to 2.5 million tonnes of LNG a year from 2005 to diversify its source of supply," the official was quoted as saying.
The paper did not say how much LNG Hungary and Spain were looking to buy.
Currently, Bosnia imports 50 million cubic metres of gas daily from Gazprom of Russia through a pipeline crossing Siberia.
The official told the paper Croatia, Austria, Bosnia, Slovenia, Hungary and Romania were planning to build a combined terminal to receive the Qatari LNG. He did not specify the location.

Qatar, which controls the world's third largest reserves of gas after Russia and Iran, aims to export 12 million tonnes a year of LNG by 2000 and up to 30 million tonnes a year by early next century to supplement its oil income -- the lowest in the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

Its two ongoing projects -- Qatar Liquefied Gas Company and Ras Laffan LNG Company -- have already signed sales-and-purchase agreements to supply six million tonnes a year to Japan and 4.8 million tonnes a year to South Korea.
A third venture -- Qatar-Enron LNG Marketing Company -- is on the drawing board.
